summary: This is an email chain between Assistant U.S. Attorneys in the Southern District of New York discussing pressure from their superiors ('the chiefs') to produce memos and written work product, specifically mentioning the Epstein case as receiving 'near-daily prodding' about imminent deadlines. The emails express frustration about the urgency of this work given the circumstances of the world (likely the COVID-19 pandemic).

persons.name: Assistant U.S. Attorney Southern District of New York
persons.context: The sender of the initial email inquiring about pressure from superiors to produce memos, specifically mentioning the Epstein case. Expresses frustration about 'near-daily prodding'.

events.title: Pressure for Epstein Case Memos
events.description: Assistant U.S. Attorneys in the SDNY report receiving significant pressure from their chiefs to produce memos and written work product related to the Epstein case, with 'near-daily prodding' about imminent deadlines.
personsInvolved: Assistant U.S. Attorney Southern District of New York

keyFacts: Prosecutors working on the Epstein case were receiving 'near-daily prodding' from their superiors ('the chiefs') about imminent deadlines for memos in April 2020.

The prosecutors found the pressure baffling and frustrating, noting the work was 'extremely time-intensive' and 'couldn't possibly be acted upon for weeks, given the circumstances of the world' (likely referencing the COVID-19 pandemic).
The email chain suggests the pressure might not have been isolated to the Epstein case, as the sender inquires if others are experiencing similar pressure.
The document reveals internal friction and stress within the prosecution team handling the Epstein case during the pandemic.
